importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article indicates the most recent update on the flooding crisis in Mexico, providing a current context for the ongoing humanitarian and environmental impact.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding events occurred over a short period last week, highlighting the sudden and severe nature of the disaster, which overwhelmed emergency response systems.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding affecting five states.

The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing, with the highest death tolls in Veracruz (29), Hidalgo (21), Puebla (13), and Queretaro (1).
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul, Veracruz (280mm) and Cuetzalan del Progreso, Puebla (286mm).
Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to deliver food, clean water, and medical aid to affected areas.
About 100,000 houses have been affected, with many near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply for approximately 263,000 users who lost power.
Governors and national authorities are coordinating relief efforts across the five affected states.
Mexico’s meteorological alert system failed to issue warnings about the extreme rainfall magnitude, raising questions about early warning effectiveness.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused devastating flooding across five Mexican states—Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro—resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, with over 280mm of rain. Government officials, including CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua and President Claudia Sheinbaum, reported widespread destruction, including the loss of around 100,000 homes and power for over 263,000 users. Thousands of military personnel have been deployed to deliver food, water, and aid to remote areas affected by landslides and road closures. The incident has raised concerns about Mexico’s meteorological alert systems, as no prior warning signs predicted the extreme rainfall magnitude.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
